title-group.article-title: Neighborhood Socioeconomic Status and New Hidradenitis Suppurativa Diagnoses in a Single Health System
title-group.alt-title: Neighborhood Socioeconomic Status and New Hidradenitis Suppurativa Diagnoses
Neighborhood Socioeconomic Status and New Hidradenitis Suppurativa Diagnoses

Role of the Funder/Sponsor: The funders had no role in the design and conduct of the study; collection, management, analysis, and interpretation of the data; preparation, review, or approval of the manuscript; and decision to submit the manuscript for publication.

sec.title: Question
sec.p: Is neighborhood-level socioeconomic status (SES) associated with a new diagnosis of hidradenitis suppurativa among dermatology patients?

sec.title: Findings
sec.p: This cross-sectional study of 65 766 dermatology patients in a single health system found that those residing in neighborhoods with lower SES had greater odds of a new hidradenitis suppurativa diagnosis compared to those in the highest-SES neighborhoods. The magnitude of the association was largest in patients residing in lowest-SES neighborhoods, and greater odds were observed among multiple racial and ethnic groups.

sec.title: Meaning
sec.p: These findings suggest that residing in a neighborhood with lower SES was associated with greater odds of a new diagnosis of hidradenitis suppurativa among dermatology patients.

sec.title: Importance
sec.p: Hidradenitis suppurativa (HS) is a chronic inflammatory skin condition. Risk factors for developing HS (eg smoking and obesity) are influenced by social drivers of health at the neighborhood level. However, the association of neighborhood-level socioeconomic status (nSES) and HS has not been adequately assessed.

sec.title: Objective
sec.p: To evaluate the association of nSES with new HS diagnoses among dermatology patients within a single health system.

sec.title: Design, Setting, and Participants
sec.p: This was a cross-sectional study of patients of the dermatology clinics at the University of California San Francisco health system between August 1, 2019, and May 31, 2024, who were also residents of the San Francisco Bay Area at index visit. Data analyses were performed from June 1, 2024, to February 11, 2025.

sec.title: Exposure
sec.p: Census tract-level index measure of nSES that incorporated income, poverty, housing cost, rental cost, education, occupation, and employment. Quintiles of nSES were assigned based on nSES distribution in the San Francisco Bay Area counties.

sec.title: Main Outcomes and Measures
sec.p: A new HS diagnosis during the study period, identified by the International Statistical Classification of Diseases and Related Health Problems, Tenth Revision code, and confirmed by medical record review. Logistic regression models were constructed and fit by generalized estimating equations accounting for clustering by census tract with nSES quintile as the primary exposure (reference used was quintile 5, the highest nSES quintile); new HS diagnosis as the binary outcome; and age, sex, and race and ethnicity as confounders. In secondary analyses, smoking status, obesity, and health insurance type were assessed as possible mediators.

sec.title: Results
sec.p: The analyses included a total of 65 766 patients (mean [SD] age, 50.4 [18.3] years; 41.8% female), of whom 485 (0.7%) had a new HS diagnosis. Greater odds of a new HS diagnosis were observed in lower-SES neighborhoods (Q1-Q4)—after adjusting for age, sex, and race and ethnicity, odds ratio for Q1 was 3.32 (95% CI, 2.46-4.49); Q2, 2.25 (95% CI, 1.62-3.12); Q3, 1.97 (95% CI, 1.46-2.66); and Q4, 1.44 (95% CI, 1.06-1.96) (P <.001 [linear trend]). In race-stratified analyses, greater odds of a new HS diagnosis were observed among patients residing in lower-SES neighborhoods, although this pattern did not reach statistical significance at the 5% level in all racial and ethnic groups.

sec.title: Conclusions and Relevance
sec.p: This cross-sectional study found that nSES was independently associated with a new diagnosis of HS among dermatology patients. This finding supports the hypothesis that neighborhood-level factors may influence the development of HS.

abstract.p: This cross-sectional study evaluates the of neighborhood socioeconomic status with new hidradenitis suppurativa diagnoses within a single health system.
